description: Probably of imitative origin. Alternatively, from dialectal yap, yaup, yalp (“to yap, yelp”), from Middle English ȝælpen, variant of yelpen (“to yelp”). More at yelp.

entries.meaning: (countable) The high-pitched bark of a small dog, or similar.

examples: Had I taken his accusations seriously I might have recommended a change in my under-managership, but I never could translate our jammy products into gas or explosives or even poison. Still yap, at least as concerned Beldite's.

entries.meaning: (countable, slang, derogatory) The mouth, which produces speech.
(countable, Tyneside) A badly behaved child; a brat.

verbs.description: yap (third-person singular simple present yaps, present participle yapping, simple past and past participle yapped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a small dog, to bark.
(intransitive, slang) To talk, especially excessively; to chatter.
examples: You’re always yapping, I wish you’d shut up.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To rob or steal from (someone).
